Award.AwardTitle: Analytical Studies of Nonlinear Optics in Periodic Media
Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this proposal is to analytically investigate novel phenomena of nonlinear light propagation in new types of periodic media. Specifically, bifurcation and linear stability of solitary waves in combined linear and nonlinear lattices, general parity-time symmetric lattices and general two-dimensional lattices will be analytically determined through the development of a sophisticated exponential asymptotics technique. Both the positions of solitary waves and their linear-stability eigenvalues will be explicitly calculated; hence the existence and linear-stability properties of these solitary waves in periodic media will be analytically obtained.

From a broader perspective, nonlinear optics in periodic media is currently at the forefront of research in optics and applied mathematics. With appropriate engineering of microscale periodic structures, light propagation can be controlled and steered in various different ways, which point to promising applications for micro-scale optical data-processing devices, low-distortion image transmission, and potential optical chips for ultrafast computers. The study of these exciting but difficult physical problems calls for advanced mathematical techniques. In this project, we will develop a powerful exponential asymptotics method, which can yield very detailed information on the existence and stability of solitary waves in periodic media. This information will allow us to assess the potential of optical solitons for various physical applications such as data processing on microscopic periodic structures. In addition, this project will facilitate interdisciplinary training of a graduate student in this important area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, nonlinear light propagation in optical media with spatially distributed gain and loss was theoretically analyzed. This physical system is dissipative due to the gain and loss, and the previous belief was that its behaviors should be totally different from those in conservative systems. However, the findings in this project revealed that if this dissipative system admits certain symmetries or is in certain special forms, then its wave behaviors become similar to those in conservative systems, which is surprising. Specifically, through the development of an exponential asymptotics methodology, it was shown that in periodic media with parity-time (PT) symmetry, i.e., when the refractive index distribution is even and the gain-loss profile odd, two continuous families of self-trapped nonlinear modes (solitons) bifurcate out from the edges of Bloch bands, with one family linearly stable and the other linearly unstable. In multi-dimensions, the concept of PT symmetry was generalized and partial PT symmetry was proposed. In addition, several classes of non-PT-symmetric optical systems were identified which share properties of PT-symmetric systems and conservative systems (such as all-real linear spectrum, continuous families of solitons and pseudo-Hamiltonian-Hopf bifurcations). These classes of non-PT systems feature novel light-guiding properties which could inspire new optical devices (such as non-PT lasers).

From a broader perspective, these findings have direct ramifications to other physical disciplines such as Bose-Einstein condensates and metamaterials (for instance, partial PT symmetry could be realized in these systems as well). In addition, a graduate student and a postdoc were trained in this interdisciplinary area of mathematics, physics and engineering. The findings of this project have also been disseminated in premier mathematics and physics journals and presented in professional conferences.  

 

More detailed outcomes of this project are summarized below.

 1. An exponential asymptotics methodology for the bifurcation and linear stability of solitons in parity-time (PT) symmetric periodic potentials was developed. Through this methodology, it was showed that two soliton families bifurcate out from each Bloch-band edge for either self-focusing or self-defocusing nonlinearity. An asymptotic expression for the eigenvalues associated with the linear stability of these soliton families was also derived. This formula shows that one of these two soliton families near band edges is always unstable, while the other can be stable.

2. A new concept of partial PT symmetry was proposed, which generalized PT symmetry to higher spatial dimensions. The usual PT symmetry requires that the potential be invariant under complex conjugation and simultaneous reflection in all spatial directions. However, we showed that if the potential is only partially PT symmetric, i.e., it is invariant under complex conjugation and reflection in a single spatial direction, then it can also possess all-real spectra and continuous families of solitons.

3. Symmetry breaking of solitons in special classes of one-dimensional and two-dimensional PT-symmetric complex potentials was reported. In generic PT-symmetric potentials, such symmetry breaking is forbidden. However, in special classes of PT-symmetric potentials, it is shown that this symmetry breaking can occur. That is, a continuous branch of non-PT-symmetric solitons can bifurcate out from the base branch of PT-symmetric solitons when the base branch’s power reaches a certain threshold.

4. An analytical method for constructing optical potentials with an arbitrary distribution of gain and loss and completely real spectrum was presented. For each arbitrary distribution of gain and loss, several classes of refractive-index profiles with freely tunable parameters were obtained such that the resulting complex potentials, although being non-PT-symmetric in general, still feature all-real spectra for a wide range of tuning parameters. These non-PT-symmetric complex potentials generalized the concept of PT-symmetric potentials to allow for more flexible gain and loss distributions while still maintaining all-real spectra.

5. Non-PT-symmetric systems admitting continuous families of solitons were analytically determined. Under a weak assumption, it was shown that stationary equations for solitons admit a constant of motion if and only if the complex potential is of a certain special form. Using this constant of motion and a novel perturbation technique, it was shown that continuous families of solitons bifurcate out from linear discrete modes in these non-PT-symmetric complex potentials.

6. Light behaviors in PT-symmetric and non-PT-symmetric systems were determined analytically near the phase transition point, where a pair of real eigenvalues of the potential coalesce and bifurcate into the complex plane. Necessary conditions for a phase transition to occur were derived based on a generalization of the Krein signature. Using the multiscale perturbation analysis, a reduced nonlinear ordinary differential equation was derived for the amplitude of localized solutions near phase transition. Predictions of this reduced model were compared to direct computations of the full system and good agreement was observed.
